script.speaker: David
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And I'm Sarah. Happy to be here!

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, I’ve got a question that’s been nagging at me. What if I told you that most people miss something incredible in the story of the Fall—something hidden in plain sight that shows it’s not just a tragedy, but a doorway to joy? Have you ever noticed that?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Oh, absolutely, David! I love that you’re pointing this out. There’s a profound shift when we look at the Fall through the lens of the Book of Moses. Let’s dive into that—it’s going to change how we see everything.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I’m all ears. Let’s frame this from different angles. How would Adam and Eve have viewed the Fall in the moment, versus how we understand it now through modern revelation? Where do we even start?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Great question. From Adam and Eve’s perspective, in Genesis 3:16-19, it must have felt like pure loss—pain, sorrow, and being cast out of Eden. But through the lens of Moses 5:11, we see their later realization. They say, ‘Blessed be the name of God, for because of my transgression my eyes are opened, and in this life I shall have joy, and again in the flesh I shall see God.’ That’s a complete pivot to hope!

script.speaker: David
script.text: Wait, that’s fascinating. So in the moment, it’s despair, but later it’s gratitude? How does that connect to Christ’s role in all this? I need to understand this shift.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly, David. Here’s where it gets powerful. In Moses 5:10-11, Adam and Eve recognize that the Fall sets the stage for redemption through Jesus Christ. Without leaving Eden, there’s no opposition, no growth, and no need for a Savior—so no path back to God. Christ turns the seeming tragedy into the possibility of eternal joy.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s remarkable. So let’s trace this pattern of opposition and redemption. I see it in the Fall, but does it echo elsewhere in scripture? Where else do we see this idea of struggle leading to salvation?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Oh, it’s everywhere once you start looking. Notice this pattern: in 2 Nephi 2:22-23, Lehi teaches that without the Fall, Adam and Eve would have remained in a state of innocence, with no children and no progression. Then fast forward to Mosiah 3:19, where we learn the natural man—born of the Fall—must yield to Christ to become a saint. It’s the same theme: opposition creates the space for redemption.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I never saw that connection so clearly! So the Fall in Genesis, Lehi’s teaching in 2 Nephi, and then Christ’s Atonement tying it together in Mosiah. It’s like a thread running through dispensations. But what’s a historical detail that might bring this alive for us?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Here’s something that creates a time collapse moment. In ancient Israelite culture, the idea of sacrifice—seen in Moses 5:5-7 with Adam offering sacrifices—was a physical reminder of loss and redemption. Scholars note that early altars were often built outside settled areas, symbolizing separation from God, much like Adam and Eve’s expulsion. Every sacrifice was a plea for reconnection, pointing to Christ’s ultimate offering.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s so vivid. I can almost feel Adam building that altar, longing to return to God’s presence. So, going back to our opening mystery—why isn’t the Fall just a tragedy? What’s the doorway to joy you hinted at?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Here’s the resolution, David. The Fall, as Moses 5:11 reveals, opens the door to joy because it allows for agency, opposition, and ultimately redemption through Christ. Adam and Eve’s choice made possible our ability to grow, repent, and return to God. It’s not a loss—it’s the first step toward becoming like Him.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s a complete game-changer. Now, are there hidden connections in these chapters most people miss? Something that ties the Fall to other parts of the plan of salvation?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Absolutely. Notice this in Moses 4:27, where the Lord clothes Adam and Eve after they try to cover themselves. This act symbolizes more than protection—it points to the Atonement. Compare it to Revelation 7:14, where the righteous are clothed in white robes, washed in the blood of the Lamb. It’s a direct line from the Fall to Christ’s covering of our sins.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I’m blown away. So the clothing in Eden is like a foreshadowing of being cleansed through Christ? That’s a connection I never made. How does that deepen our understanding of the temple today?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It’s profound, isn’t it? In the temple, sacred clothing reminds us of this same covering—Christ’s Atonement protecting and preparing us to return to God’s presence. It echoes back to Eden, showing that the plan of salvation was in place from the very beginning. It’s a beautiful, hidden thread.

script.speaker: David
script.text: This changes how I read the story entirely. So, bringing this to our lives today, how can understanding the Fall as a step toward joy influence the way we face challenges?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s the key application. When we face pain or opposition, we can remember Adam and Eve’s realization in Moses 5:11—that through Christ, our struggles lead to growth and joy. We can choose to see difficulties as part of the path back to God, trusting in His redemptive power.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s so hopeful. Sarah, as we wrap up, what’s one invitation you’d give our listeners based on what we’ve discovered together?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I’d invite everyone to reread Moses 5:10-11 this week and ponder how the Fall, through Christ, brings joy into your life. Write down one challenge you’re facing and how trusting in the Savior can turn it into a step toward growth. It’s a powerful way to feel connected to Adam and Eve’s journey.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I love that. Thank you, Sarah, for these incredible insights. Listeners, join us next time as we continue to uncover the wonders of the scriptures together.
